subsection_header_2: United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.
subsection_content_2: The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) recently reported a decline in H5N1 avian influenza outbreaks in poultry and wild birds over the past year, especially in the second quarter.  From April to June of this year, six countries, Bangladesh, Cambodia, China, Egypt, India, and Indonesia, reported 98 domestic poultry outbreaks and 5 wild bird outbreaks, compared to 508 outbreaks during the same time last year.  While the decline is good news, the FAO cautions that “not all outbreaks are reported, making it difficult to tell if the world has actually made progress in H5N1 control.”  The report also confirmed that during the second quarter, nine human cases of the H5N1 have been reported in Cambodia, China, Egypt, and Indonesia.
subsection_content_4: On lakes near the Black Sea in the southern Krasnodar region of Russia, officials recently confirmed that about 4,000 wild ducks have been found dead.  A spokeswoman from Rosselkhoznadzor, Russia’s Federal Service for Veterinary and Phytosanitary Surveillance, said that the birds’ remains are being tested and the H5 virus is being confirmed and blamed for the deaths.  To prevent further outbreaks, poultry and humans are being vaccinated.
subsection_content_1: United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.
subsection_content_3: The Animal Disease Control Center of Chiayi County has placed a ban on the movement of chickens at a chicken farm in Puzih City after discovering cases of low-pathogenic H5N2 avian influenza.  Because the virus is low-pathogenic, the 15,700 chickens will not be culled; rather, they will be monitored and the eggs will be disinfected before being sold.  All poultry farms within a 3-kilometer radius are being monitored for further outbreaks.
